Article Title: Pakistan coach fires stern warning to India before Asia Cup final clash in Dubai
Article Text:
Pakistan's Shaheen Shah Afridi celebrates with teammates (AP Photo/Altaf Qadri)

'My job is to play': Haris Rauf stays calm as Pakistan ride out Asia Cup drama

Poll Will Pakistan successfully put India under pressure in the Asia Cup final? Yes, they will pressure India No, India will dominate

Pakistan head coach Mike Hesson urged his players to concentrate on cricket ahead of their historic first-ever Asia Cup final against India on Sunday in Dubai, following heightened tensions during their previous two encounters since the May military conflict between the nations. Pakistan secured their place in the final by defeating Bangladesh by 11 runs in Thursday's Super Four match in Dubai.The previous two India-Pakistan matches in this Asia Cup were marked by controversy, with both teams refusing to shake hands after both games.The matches saw various controversial gestures, with Indian captain Suryakumar Yadav accused of making a political statement after the first match, while Pakistan's Sahibzada Farhan and Haris Rauf made aggressive gestures in the second."Look, my message to the players is just focus on cricket and that certainly we will be doing. In terms of gestures there has always been passion in terms of high-pressure games," said Hesson.India has dominated the recent encounters, winning both matches in this tournament - by seven wickets in the Group A match and by six wickets in the Super Four stage.India's supremacy extends to a seven-match winning streak against Pakistan across formats since 2022, including three ODIs and four T20Is."We have to be good enough to put India under pressure for longer because there is a reason why they are ranked the top side in the world," Hesson said. "We have to put them under pressure and that will be our challenge."Pakistan's performance has shown improvement between the two matches. They scored only 127-9 in the first game, which India easily chased down."I think the way we played against India in the last match was a huge step up from the first game," said Hesson. "The first game was a bit passive, we allowed India to control the game.""The last match we had that game by the scruff of the neck for long periods and it took an exceptional innings from Abhishek Sharma that took the game away from us."In the second match, Pakistan posted a more competitive total, but Abhishek Sharma's impressive 74 runs off 39 balls helped India successfully chase down the 172-run target."We have deserved this opportunity so it's now up to us to make the most of it," said Hesson. "We have been trying to be in a position to win the trophy."The former New Zealand coach believes his team must maintain pressure throughout the final to have a chance at victory against the world champions.
Article Summary: Pakistan to play India in first-ever Asia Cup final on Sunday in Dubai. Pakistan defeated Bangladesh by 11 runs in Thursday's Super Four match. India has dominated the recent encounters, winning both matches in this tournament. Pakistan coach Mike Hesson says his team must put India under pressure.

Article Title: 'Mark my words': Shoaib Akhtar tells Pakistan how to beat India in Asia Cup final
Article Text:
Pakistan's players celebrates the dismissal of Bangladesh's Nurul Hasan (AP Photo/Altaf Qadri)

Pakistan coach fires warning ahead of Asia Cup final

Poll Which player do you think is the key for India's victory? Abhishek Sharma Shubman Gill Suryakumar Yadav Jasprit Bumrah

Former Pakistan fast bowler Shoaib Akhtar shared his insights ahead of the Asia Cup 2025 final between India and Pakistan at the Dubai International Stadium on Sunday, emphasizing that Pakistan can overcome their previous two losses against India in the tournament if they focus on dismissing key Indian batsman Abhishek Sharma early and maintain an aggressive approach.Pakistan's recent encounters with India in the Asia Cup 2025 have been marked by heated exchanges, particularly during the Super 4s match where Pakistani pacers Haris Rauf and Shaheen Shah Afridi engaged in verbal confrontations with Indian openers Abhishek Sharma and Shubman Gill , though India emerged victorious.Abhishek Sharma has been instrumental in India's success throughout the tournament, scoring 74 runs off 35 balls in the previous match against Pakistan, which helped India chase down 172 runs with seven balls remaining. He also demonstrated his batting prowess against Bangladesh with a quick-fire 75 runs off 37 balls.Akhtar specifically highlighted the importance of targeting Abhishek Sharma in the early overs of the match. "Come out of this mindset, keep their aura aside. Just break their aura. Just play with this mindset that you had in the match against Bangladesh. This is the kind of mindset you need. You don't need to bowl 20 overs; you just need to get wickets," Akhtar said on the 'Game On Hai' programme."Mark my words, if Abhishek Sharma gets out in the first two overs, they will get in trouble. The starts they are getting, they are going to struggle if Abhishek gets out early. It's not like that, Abhishek will not mistime the ball; he will do that; you just need to go for the kill. If you come out fighting, India will realise that we have to work hard for our runs," Akhtar added.The Rawalpindi Express also shared his perspective on India's head coach Gautam Gambhir 's likely approach to the final. "I know Gautam Gambhir. He will tell his team that 'you need to bring your A game against Pakistan'. Pakistan will play the worst cricket, they will pick the worst side, but as soon as they reach the final, they play the best cricket, and they win the finals. It has happened so my times with us," said Akhtar.Before the highly anticipated final, India is scheduled to play their last Super 4s match against Sri Lanka on Friday, September 26, at the Dubai International Stadium.The former Pakistani speedster, known for being one of the fastest bowlers in cricket history, advised Pakistan's team to shed their inhibitions and adopt an aggressive mindset similar to their approach against Bangladesh.The upcoming final presents an opportunity for Pakistan to reverse their fortunes against India in the tournament, where they have faced defeats in their previous encounters despite showing competitive spirit and engaging in intense on-field battles.The match promises to be a crucial contest between two cricket powerhouses, with Pakistan looking to overcome their recent setbacks and India aiming to maintain their winning momentum in the tournament.
Article Summary: Pakistan face India in the Asia Cup 2025 final at the Dubai International Stadium on Sunday. Former Pakistan fast bowler Shoaib Akhtar shared his insights ahead of the match. He said Pakistan can overcome their previous two losses against India if they focus on dismissing key Indian batsman Abhishek Sharma early and maintain an aggressive approach.

Article Title: 'India ko chhodna nahi' – Pakistani fan goes viral shaking hands with Haris Rauf ahead of Asia Cup final
Article Text:
Pakistan's Haris Rauf celebrates with teammates (AP Photo/Altaf Qadri)

“India ko chhodna nahi h”

Shaheen Afridi press conference: Hits back at Suryakumar Yadav, Haris Rauf controversy and tension

“good enough to beat anyone”

As Pakistan booked their place in the Asia Cup final, a short video went viral that left many Indian fans shaking their heads. In the clip, a Pakistani supporter shakes hands with Haris Rauf and tells him,– a phrase dripping with provocation and disrespect. The moment has added fuel to the fiery build-up for Sunday’s final in Dubai.Click here to watch the video Pakistan’s journey to the final was hardly convincing. Their batters struggled against Bangladesh, managing just 135 in 20 overs on a tricky pitch. But the bowlers, led by Shaheen Shah Afridi and Rauf, staged a fightback to defend the modest total by 11 runs. Their victory set up a third clash with India in the tournament – one that promises high tension both on and off the field.The final is already steeped in controversy. In the two previous India-Pakistan encounters, there were no post-match handshakes, while Rauf’s “6-0” and fighter-jet gestures against Indian fans drew global criticism. Sahibzada Farhan even mimicked firing a gun with his bat, turning cricket into a theatre of political provocation.Now, Pakistani fans are echoing the same hostile attitude. For Indian supporters, it’s hard not to feel anger at this constant disrespect. Yet, as captain Salman Ali Agha claims, his team is. That may be, but on Sunday, it is India’s skill, discipline, and composure that will speak louder than any gestures or slogans.The stage is set for a clash of cricket and pride. India must not just win the trophy, but also show that such theatrics and provocation will never overshadow the sport.
Article Summary: Pakistan face India in the Asia Cup final in Dubai on Sunday. Pakistan beat Bangladesh by 11 runs to reach the final. A video of a Pakistani fan telling Haris Rauf, "India ko chhodna nahi h" has gone viral. The moment has added fuel to the fiery build-up for the match.

India managed a 41-run win over Bangladesh on Wednesday, but the team’s fielding remained a major concern. The side dropped five catches in the match, bringing their tournament total to 12 missed chances, the most by any team so far in the Asia Cup.With a catching efficiency of just 67.5 per cent, India rank second-worst behind Hong Kong China. The game also marked one of the rare instances in T20Is where a single batter saw four catches dropped off them in an innings, a feat previously recorded by Jason Roy, Mohammad Hafeez, Pathum Nissanka, and now Saif Hassan Varun acknowledged the team’s shortcomings but stressed the importance of improvement. “This team has been picked for a mission till the World Cup. We have to pick up our fielding and the fielding coach will have lots to say. Last match he didn’t say much, but after today he’ll have plenty to say,” he said.He also pointed to the challenges of playing under the “Ring of Fire” floodlights and in high humidity. “It comes into your eyesight sometimes and it’s a bit of a disturbance. We have to get used to it. But at this level, you cannot make excuses. We have to take every catch,” Varun added.During the match, Bangladesh’s Saif Hassan was dropped four times at critical moments on scores of 40, 60, 65, and 69. Despite these opportunities, India’s spinners eventually shared seven wickets among them, with Kuldeep Yadav leading the charge with 3 for 18. Varun Chakravarthy took 2 for 29, Axar Patel 1 for 37, and part-timer Tilak Varma contributed to wrapping up the innings. Suryakumar Yadav also effected a key run-out to further restrict Bangladesh’s chase.The team’s struggles under pressure highlight that, while India’s batters and bowlers have been effective, fielding improvements are essential for high-level success.
Article Summary: India managed a 41-run win over Bangladesh on Wednesday, but the team’s fielding remained a major concern. The side dropped five catches in the match, bringing their tournament total to 12 missed chances. With a catching efficiency of just 67.5 per cent, India rank second-worst behind Hong Kong China.

Article Title: Rohit Sharma stuns fans with 10 kg transformation ahead of ODI comeback – See new look

'Never Dreamt of This...': Rohit Sharma's BIG CONFESSION After Retirement From Test Cricket

India ODI captain Rohit Sharma is making headlines ahead of his much-awaited return to international cricket next month, revealing a striking transformation after shedding 10 kilograms. Former India batting coach and close friend Abhishek Nayar shared a glimpse of Rohit’s new look during a training session in Mumbai, writing, “10,000 grams later, we keep pushing.”The 38-year-old is expected to be back in action on October 19, when India begin their three-match ODI series against Australia. The two senior batters had retired from T20 internationals last June after India’s T20 World Cup triumph in Barbados and stepped away from Test cricket in May, just days before India’s England tour.Both Rohit and Kohli have completed their mandatory pre-season fitness tests. Rohit trained in Bengaluru at the BCCI ’s Centre of Excellence, extending his sessions to focus on the upcoming ODI series. Kohli, who has relocated to London following the IPL 2025 season, completed his fitness assessments there.With just weeks to go before India’s first ODI in Australia, all eyes are on Rohit’s form and fitness as he aims to lead the team in the three-match series starting October 19.

Article Title: India announce new vice-captain for West Indies Tests; Karun Nair dropped
Article Text:
India will play two Test matches against West Indies, starting October 2.

Mentally tuned and match ready: Karun Nair makes impactful IPL return

India Test squad vs West Indies:

India have named a 15-member squad for the two Tests against West Indies with Ravindra Jadeja getting named as the vice-captain and as expected, Karun Nair not being named in the lineup. Devdutt Padikkal has been named in the lineup."Frankly, we expected a little bit more. I mean, he's played four Tests. That's the way it is, I mean, we feel (Devdutt) Padikkal offers a little bit more at this point. And I wish we could give everyone 15 or 20 Tests. Unfortunately, it doesn't work that way. Padikkal's been in the Test squad. I mean, he was in the Test squad in Australia, played in Dharamshala against England, got a 50 there. So he's shown some decent form with India," said chief selector Ajit Agarkar during the press conference in Dubai."Frankly, we expected a bit more from Karun on the England trip there"Another absentee from the squad is Abhimanyu Easwaran, whose wait to represent India continues to get longer having been named in the squads for Australia and England but only warming the bench."We don't need a third opener at home," said Agarkar on Abhimanyu's absence from the lineup.Rishabh Pant has not yet recovered enough to be included in the squad. He served as vice-captain during the England tour. Taking his place as the second-in-command is Ravindra Jadeja.Dhruv Jurel and N. Jagadeesan are the two specialist wicketkeepers, with Jurel likely to be the first-choice option.The rest of the squad has a familiar look, and given the expectation that spin will play a larger role at home than pace, India have named Ravindra Jadeja, Washington Sundar, and Axar Patel as the three spin-bowling allrounders, alongside Kuldeep Yadav.Nitish Kumar Reddy is listed as the fast-bowling allrounder, with Jasprit Bumrah, Mohammed Siraj, and Prasidh Krishna as the first-choice pacers.Shubman Gill (c), Yashasvi Jaiswal, KL Rahul, Sai Sudharsan, Devdutt Padikkal, Dhruv Jurel, Ravindra Jadeja, Washington Sundar, Jasprit Bumrah, Axar Patel, Nitish Kumar Reddy, N Jagadeesan, Mohammed Siraj, Prasidh Krishna, Kuldeep YadavThis series marks India’s first home campaign under new Test captain Shubman Gill, who previously steered the team to a 2-2 draw with England. It was India’s first series of the 2025-2027 World Test Championship cycle.The opening Test against the West Indies will take place at the Narendra Modi Stadium in Ahmedabad starting October 2, with the second Test in New Delhi, at the Arun Jaitley Stadium, beginning October 10.The West Indies squad was scheduled to arrive in Ahmedabad on September 24 and will undergo a training camp ahead of the first Test.This series represents the second assignment in the new ICC WTC cycle for the Roston Chase-led side, following their home series against Australia in June-July. Left-arm spinner Khary Pierre, who earned his maiden Test call-up, has been a notable inclusion.Pierre, 33, has been rewarded for consistent performances in the West Indies Championship, where he topped the wicket tally last season with 41 wickets at an average of 13.56. Tagenarine Chanderpaul, son of West Indian batting great Shivnarine Chanderpaul, is also part of the squad.With Ajit Agarkar, the chairman of the selection committee, currently in the United Arab Emirates for the Asia Cup, the meeting to pick the squad was conducted online. This selection process was also the last for two committee members — S. Sharath and Subroto Banerjee.During the BCCI AGM on September 28, Sharath and Banerjee were replaced by Pragyan Ojha (South Zone) and R.P. Singh (Central Zone).
Article Summary: India have named a 15-member squad for the two Tests against West Indies. Ravindra Jadeja gets named as the vice-captain. Devdutt Padikkal has been named in the lineup. As expected, Karun Nair has not been named. The opening Test will take place in Ahmedabad starting October 2.

Article Title: RECORD BREAKER! Vaibhav Sooryavanshi hits six sixes against Australia U19s in match, registers Youth ODIs milestone

Indian teenage cricket sensation Vaibhav Sooryavanshi has set a new record for most career sixes in Youth ODI cricket, surpassing Unmukt Chand's previous mark of 38 maximums. The accolade came during the second India U-19 vs Australia U-19 50-over match at the Ian Healy Oval in Brisbane on Wednesday.The 14-year-old left-handed batter achieved this milestone in just 10 innings, compared to Chand's 21 matches, while scoring 70 runs off 68 balls against Australia before being dismissed by Australian captain Yash Deshmukh.Sooryavanshi has now accumulated 540 runs in Youth ODIs, with 26% of his runs coming from boundaries. His current tally stands at 41 sixes, establishing him as the new record holder in this category.The young prodigy's achievement adds to his growing list of records in youth cricket. Following Sooryavanshi and Chand in the list of Indians with most sixes in Youth One-Day cricket is Yashasvi Jaiswal, who recorded 30 sixes in 27 matches between 2018 and 2020.Sooryavanshi's cricket journey has been marked by several groundbreaking achievements. He recently became the youngest player to participate in the Indian Premier League, where he scored the second-fastest century in the league's history and became its youngest centurion.His entry into first-class cricket was equally notable. During the 2023-24 Ranji Trophy season, he made his debut at 12 years and 284 days against Mumbai, securing his place as the youngest player in the tournament's history.The young cricketer from Samastipur has also claimed the record for the fastest Youth ODI hundred, completing his century in 52 balls. This performance surpassed the previous world record held by Pakistan's Kamran Ghulam, who had scored a 53-ball century in 2019.In the same innings, Sooryavanshi set an Indian record by hitting 10 sixes in a single match. At 13 years and 188 days, he became the youngest centurion in competitive cricket's 170-year history.His remarkable performances extended to Test cricket at the youth level, where he scored a 58-ball hundred against Australia in the 1st Youth Test in Chennai. This innings stands as the second-fastest century at this level, just behind England's Moeen Ali's 56-ball hundred.
Article Summary: Vaibhav Sooryavanshi has set a new record for most career sixes in Youth ODI cricket. The 14-year-old left-handed batter achieved this milestone in just 10 innings, compared to Unmukt Chand's previous mark of 38 maximums. The young cricketer from Samastipur has also claimed the record for the fastest Youth O DI hundred, completing his century in 52 balls.

Article Title: Ajit Agarkar explains why Shreyas Iyer won’t play West Indies Tests
Article Text:
Shreyas Iyer (PTI Photo/Shailendra Bhojak)

Ajit Agarkar press conference: On Shreyas Iyer, Pant injury, Bumrah availability & why Karun dropped

The BCCI on Thursday announced India’s 15-member squad for the two home Tests against the West Indies, led by Shubman Gill, with senior all-rounder Ravindra Jadeja named vice-captain and Devdutt Padikkal making a return.One of the notable absentees is Shreyas Iyer . Chief selector Ajit Agarkar addressed his unavailability, saying, “Shreyas is a senior player. He has led India A as well, and we are always looking to develop leadership qualities in multiple players. Unfortunately, he won’t be available because of his fitness. More than anything, we want him playing and playing well.”Iyer is currently captaining the India A squad for three 50-over matches against Australia A in Kanpur starting September 30. He had led India A in the first unofficial four-day Test against Australia A but withdrew from the second, requesting a six-month break from red-ball cricket due to ongoing back concerns. The BCCI has approved his request. Shreyas Iyer has informed the BCCI of his decision to take a six-month break from red-ball cricket. Having undergone back surgery in the UK and managed his recovery well, he has recently experienced recurring back spasms and stiffness while playing the longer format.He wishes to utilise this period to build endurance, body resilience and work on his fitness.Iyer first faced back issues in December 2022, which reoccurred during India’s home Border-Gavaskar Trophy series in March 2023. Following surgery in April 2023, he missed the IPL and was later dropped midway through India’s home series against England in February 2024.Despite these setbacks, Iyer remains a key white-ball performer. He was India’s top scorer in the Champions Trophy earlier this year with 243 runs in five innings and led Punjab Kings to the IPL 2025 final. The break will allow him to focus on fitness and white-ball preparations while the selectors manage his long-term workload.
Article Summary: Shreyas Iyer will take a six-month break from red-ball cricket due to ongoing back concerns. Iyer is currently captaining the India A squad for three 50-over matches against Australia A in Kanpur starting September 30. The break will allow him to focus on fitness and white-ball preparations while the selectors manage his long-term workload.

Article Title: 'We still have a point to prove': Sri Lanka to take fight to India in Asia Cup
Article Text:
India vs Sri Lanka (AP)

Sri Lankan all-rounder Dasun Shanaka expressed optimism for a competitive match against India in their final Super Four game of the Asia Cup in Dubai, despite his team's elimination from the tournament. Speaking ahead of the dead rubber match, Shanaka emphasized that Sri Lanka still has a point to prove before the T20 World Cup next year, which India and Sri Lanka will co-host.India has already secured their spot in the Asia Cup final against Pakistan, while Sri Lanka was eliminated after two losses in the Super Four stage following an unbeaten run in the group phase."The best opponent in the tournament. We are looking for a fine match and need to prove a point. We are still good enough, but unfortunately out. But we've got a World Cup coming up, so this is a good clash against India. So, the boys have got a point to prove in this competition before leaving Dubai," Shanaka told ANI.Shanaka has demonstrated consistent performance against India in T20Is, scoring 430 runs in 22 innings at an average of 26.87, with two fifties and a strike rate above 140. His highest score remains an unbeaten 74.The Sri Lankan all-rounder praised India's dominance in T20 cricket over the past decade and acknowledged their system's effectiveness. He specifically mentioned Indian T20I captain Suryakumar Yadav as a "big match player" despite his current form."Yeah, see, I like the way SKY (Suryakumar) plays. He has not scored many runs in this competition. But you know, he is a big match player and with the bowling, of course, Jasprit Bumrah ," Shanaka stated.Suryakumar has struggled in the tournament, scoring only 59 runs in four innings, with his highest being 47 not out against Pakistan. His 2023 performance has been particularly challenging, with just 87 runs in nine innings at an average of 12.42 and a strike rate of 112.98.Shanaka also commended Abhishek Sharma 's performance, noting, "Abhishek Sharma in his prime form from IPL. So yeah, really happy for him."Abhishek Sharma leads the tournament's run-scoring charts with 248 runs in five innings, averaging 49.60 with a strike rate of 206.66. He needs just 34 runs to surpass Pakistan's Mohammed Rizwan's record for the highest runs in a T20I Asia Cup.Sharma's overall T20 performance in 2023 has been impressive, accumulating 966 runs in 23 innings at an average of 42, maintaining a strike rate above 203, with two centuries and five fifties.The Sri Lanka squad includes Pathum Nissanka, Kusal Mendis, Kusal Perera, Charith Asalanka, Kamindu Mendis, Dasun Shanaka, Wanindu Hasaranga , Chamika Karunaratne, Dushmantha Chameera , Maheesh Theekshana, Nuwan Thushara, Dunith Wellalage, Kamil Mishara, Nuwanidu Fernando, Binura Fernando, and Janith Liyanage.India's squad comprises Abhishek Sharma, Shubman Gill, Shivam Dube, Suryakumar Yadav, Hardik Pandya , Tilak Varma, Axar Patel, Sanju Samson, Kuldeep Yadav, Jasprit Bumrah, Varun Chakaravarthy, Arshdeep Singh, Harshit Rana, Rinku Singh, and Jitesh Sharma.
Article Summary: Sri Lankan all-rounder Dasun Shanaka expressed optimism for a competitive match against India. India has already secured their spot in the Asia Cup final against Pakistan. Sri Lanka was eliminated after two losses in the Super Four stage following an unbeaten run in the group phase.

Article Title: Legendary Pakistani pacer slams cricketer: 'This guy needs to be benched'
Article Text:
Pakistan's Saim Ayub, left, celebrates with teammates (AP Photo/Altaf Qadri)

Pakistan cricket player Saim Ayub's batting struggles continued as he registered his fourth duck in five innings during Thursday's Asia Cup Super Four match against Bangladesh, leading former Pakistan captain Waqar Younis to call for his removal from the playing XI. The 23-year-old all-rounder, who has only managed to score 21 runs against India in the tournament, has however picked up six wickets with his bowling performances.Ayub's latest dismissal came while attempting to hit Mahedi Hasan's full delivery over the in-field, resulting in a catch at mid-on after the ball hit the inner half of his bat. This continued his poor run of form with the bat in the tournament.Despite Ayub's contributions with the ball, Waqar Younis expressed concerns about his batting form during his commentary on SonyLiv. The Pakistan cricket legend emphasized the need to protect young talent by occasionally removing them from the playing XI."Look, I said it after the second duck, I said this guy needs to be benched. It's not that he is not talented; he is very talented. I think he is the future of Pakistan cricket. But sometimes when things are not going right for you, you just keep going in the shell, keep going down and down, and that's what is happening here with him. His body language was poor this afternoon when he walked onto the field," Younis stated.Younis further elaborated on his stance regarding Ayub's position in the team, highlighting the importance of focusing on his batting rather than his bowling abilities."You know, he is a youngster, you really need to look after them sometimes, by just not playing them sometimes. Pakistan kept on playing him, just purely because he can bowl. You don't need to worry about his bowling; Pakistan needs to worry about his batting. If he is going to give us runs or not. At the moment, it's not happening. He needs to dig deeper in his game to score a few runs," Younis added.The young all-rounder's only successful batting performance in the tournament came against India in the Super Four stage, where he scored 21 runs from 17 balls. This remains his sole contribution with the bat across his five innings in the 2025 Asia Cup.Ayub's bowling performances have been a bright spot for Pakistan, with six wickets to his name before the Bangladesh fixture. However, his batting struggles have overshadowed his bowling contributions.The discussion around Ayub's position in the team highlights the broader challenge of managing young talent in international cricket, particularly when players face extended periods of poor form in one aspect of their game while performing well in another.The situation presents a dilemma for the Pakistan team management, who must balance the development of a young talent considered to be the future of Pakistan cricket with the immediate needs of the team in an important tournament like the Asia Cup.Ayub's recent dismissals and body language on the field have raised concerns about his confidence levels, which Younis suggests could be addressed by temporarily removing him from the playing XI to help him regain his batting form.The ongoing debate about Ayub's place in the team reflects the challenges of international cricket, where players must maintain consistent performances across all aspects of their game to justify their selection in the playing XI.
Article Summary: Pakistan cricket player Saim Ayub's batting struggles continued as he registered his fourth duck in five innings during Thursday's Asia Cup Super Four match against Bangladesh. The 23-year-old all-rounder, who has only managed to score 21 runs against India in the tournament, has however picked up six wickets with his bowling performances. Former Pakistan captain Waqar Younis has called for his removal from the playing XI.

Article Title: First time ever! Pakistan beat Bangladesh, set up Asia Cup final against India
Article Text:
India will face Pakistan in the final on Sunday (Images via Getty Images)

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel. SUBSCRIBE NOW!

Hussain Talat on morale in Pakistan camp after Asia Cup Super 4s loss to India

Poll Who do you think will win the final match between Pakistan and India in the Asia Cup 2025? Pakistan India Too close to call

In a virtual semifinal in the Asia Cup Super Fours in Dubai, Pakistan edged past Bangladesh in a tense low-scoring contest on Thursday to set up a third clash with India in the competition.On a humid evening, Bangladesh bowlers once again impressed, but Pakistan’s lower order ensured they finished with a competitive 135 for eight from 20 overs. That total, though modest, proved sufficient on a surface where batting was never easy. Pakistan ended up securing a 11-run victory, and with that, another clash with rivals India.This also marks the first-ever meeting between the two teams in the final of the competition. In the last 16 editions of the Asia Cup, the two teams hadn't met in the summit clash.Taskin Ahmed gave Bangladesh the early breakthrough, removing Sahibzada Farhan for four. Saim Ayub fell soon after for a duck, while Fakhar Zaman (13), Hussain Talat (3) and captain Salman Ali Agha (19) also departed cheaply, leaving Pakistan reeling at 49 for five.Mohammad Haris offered some resistance with a quick 31 off 23 balls before being dismissed by Mahedi Hasan. From there, Shaheen Shah Afridi’s 19 and Mohammad Nawaz’s lively 25 off 15 balls gave Pakistan much-needed momentum. Faheem Ashraf’s unbeaten 14 at the back end took them past 130.For Bangladesh, Taskin was the main man of the attack with 3 for 28, while spinner Rishad Hossain (2/18) and Mahedi Hasan (2/28) exploited the conditions well. Mustafizur Rahman also chipped in with one wicket.In reply, Bangladesh never really settled into their chase. Early strikes by Shaheen Afridi put them under pressure, dismissing Parvez Hossain Emon and Towhid Hridoy inside the powerplay.Nurul Hasan managed 16 before falling to Saim Ayub, while captain Jaker Ali (5) also fell cheaply.Shamim Hossain’s 30 gave Bangladesh a glimmer of hope, but with the required rate climbing, Pakistan’s bowlers closed out the contest. The flurry of wickets from Pakistan pacer Haris Rauf, where he dismissed both Tanzim Hasan Sakib and Taskin Ahmed in the 18th over left Bangladesh on the brink.In his final over, which was also the last of the match, he conceded 11 runs, but had enough runs to spare to ensure victory.With this result, Pakistan confirmed their spot in the final, where they will meet India once again in what promises to be another tense clash in Dubai. With controversy surrounding the India-Pakistan clash and the stakes higher than ever, Sunday's clash will be the perfect finale for Asia Cup 2025.
Article Summary: Pakistan beat Bangladesh by 11 runs in the Asia Cup Super 4s in Dubai. Pakistan will now face India in the final of the competition on Sunday. This will be the first time the two teams have met in a final. The final will be held at the Dubai International Cricket Stadium.

Article Title: India women off to poor start, suffer 153-run defeat against England in warm-up clash
Article Text:
Jemimah Rodrigues's 66 was not enough for India to avoid defeat vs England in the first warm-up matcg (Image via X/@BCCIWomen)

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel. SUBSCRIBE NOW!

Poll Should India reconsider their batting order following this match? Yes No

India began their ICC Women’s World Cup preparations in concerning fashion, losing to England by 153 runs in their warm-up fixture at Bengaluru on Thursday.Batting first, the visitors posted a commanding 339 for nine in 50 overs. Captain Nat Sciver-Brunt was the star, striking 122 off 105 balls, an innings featuring 13 fours and two sixes. She was well supported by Emma Lamb, who smashed 84 from 60 deliveries, hitting 12 boundaries to pile pressure on India’s bowlers.Amy Jones (39) and skipper Heather Knight (37) chipped in with valuable runs at the top, ensuring England maintained momentum throughout their innings. For India, Kranti Goud stood out with the ball, returning figures of 3 for 31 in five overs.India’s reply began with promise. Uma Chetry gave the hosts a bright start with 45 off 50 balls, before Jemimah Rodrigues anchored the innings with a strong 66 from 68 deliveries, including eight fours. However, the rest of the batting order crumbled against powerful English bowling. Richa Ghosh’s 21 was the only other score of note as India were bowled out for 187 in 34 overs.Linsey Smith (2/35) and Sophie Ecclestone (2/38) led the attack for England, with wickets shared across the bowling unit.The result showed England’s strong build-up to the tournament, while India were left with concerns after a poor showing with both bat and ball.India will look to bounce back when they face New Zealand in their final warm-up game on Saturday. England’s next fixture is a high-profile clash against Australia on Sunday, ahead of the World Cup opener on September 30.
Article Summary: England beat India by 153 runs in first warm-up match. Nat Sciver-Brunt top scored for England with 122 off 105 balls. India were bowled out for 187 in 34 overs. Jemimah Rodrigues top scored with 66 for India.

Article Title: Jasprit Bumrah's selection for West Indies Tests slammed - 'Seems like a missed opportunity'
Article Text:
Jasprit Bumrah has been included in the Test squad for the matches against West Indies (Photo by Clive Mason/Getty Images)

Big Change in India’s XI! No Jasprit Bumrah vs Oman?

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel. SUBSCRIBE NOW!

Poll Should India have included a younger fast bowler instead of Jasprit Bumrah in the squad? Yes, it’s a missed opportunity No, Bumrah is essential for the team

Former India all-rounder Irfan Pathan has questioned the decision to include Jasprit Bumrah in the squad for the upcoming home Test series against West Indies, calling it a missed opportunity to test a younger fast bowler.Bumrah, who bowled in only three of the five Tests on the recent England tour, was named in the 15-member squad for the series starting October 2 in Ahmedabad. Pathan said on his YouTube channel that while Bumrah’s commitment to Test cricket is admirable, selectors could have used this series to look at fresh pace options.“It seems like a missed opportunity not to play a young fast bowler in these two Tests, but that’s the team’s current direction. If I were a selector or manager, I would have surely tried to give a young fast bowler an opportunity, focusing on their development, not just quick results. Bumrah remains committed to Test cricket, which is fantastic,” Pathan said.He felt Indian conditions, where spinners usually dominate, were ideal to rest Bumrah and manage his workload. “Still, it’s good that Bumrah maintains Test cricket as his priority. Selectors could have utilised this series to give proper rest to Bumrah and groom a young fast bowler, something India must prioritise for long-term vision.India needs a group of eight good fast bowlers, not just three or four,” he added.Pathan also welcomed the return of Axar Patel, saying his presence strengthens India’s depth. “Axar’s return strengthens the team. When Axar plays alongside Washington and Jadeja, the team gains batting depth. Does this mean Kuldeep Yadav may miss out again? I would definitely want to see him play, but with home conditions generally allowing only two fast bowlers, his spot is not guaranteed,” he said.With this being India’s first home Test series after Ravichandran Ashwin’s retirement, Pathan raised the question of who will take up his mantle. “Who will fill that Ashwin role? Washington Sundar brings some qualities, but he does not have all of Ashwin’s traits… Jadeja supported Ashwin well, but now someone new must step up for that role. Could it be Kuldeep Yadav or Washington Sundar, or even Axar Patel? Each offers something different,” he said.
Article Summary: Former India all-rounder Irfan Pathan has questioned the decision to include Jasprit Bumrah in the squad for the upcoming home Test series against West Indies. Pathan said selectors could have used this series to look at fresh pace options. He also welcomed the return of Axar Patel.

Article Title: Massive blow! India pacer suffers freak injury; doubt for women's ODI World Cup
Article Text:
Arundhati Reddy was taken off in a warm-up match against England (Screengrabs/ICC)

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel. SUBSCRIBE NOW!

India skipper Harmanpreet Kaur under pressure ahead of ICC Women's ODI World Cup 2025?

Poll Do you think Arundhati Reddy will recover in time for the ICC Women's Cricket World Cup? Yes, she will recover quickly No, she will miss the tournament

India’s World Cup preparations suffered a setback on Thursday after pacer Arundhati Reddy was wheelchaired off the field during the warm-up match against England in Bengaluru.The incident occurred in Reddy’s follow-through while bowling to England captain Heather Knight. Attempting to take a return catch, she landed awkwardly on her left leg and collapsed on the ground. Medical staff rushed in to assist her, but she had to be taken off on a wheelchair.Before the injury, Reddy had given India an early breakthrough by dismissing opener Amy Jones.The 27-year-old seamer has become an important part of India’s pace attack since her debut last year. In 11 ODIs, she has picked up 15 wickets at an average of 32.66, with best figures of 4 for 26. She also impressed against Australia recently, taking four wickets across two matches, including a three-wicket haul in Delhi. This year, she has claimed seven wickets in six ODIs.Her availability for the upcoming ICC Women’s Cricket World Cup now remains in doubt, with the extent of the injury yet to be confirmed.India, two-time finalists in 2005 and 2017, are chasing their maiden World Cup title on home soil. They begin their campaign against Sri Lanka in Guwahati on September 30.At the time of Reddy’s injury, England were strongly placed at 214 for 3 in the 36th over after being put in to bat. They ended with 339 at the loss of 9 wickets.
Article Summary: Arundhati Reddy was taken off in a warm-up match against England. She landed awkwardly on her left leg and collapsed on the ground. The 27-year-old seamer has become an important part of India’s pace attack since her debut last year.

Article Title: Jasprit Bumrah blasts former India cricketer for being 'inaccurate'
Article Text:
Jasprit Bumrah has called out Mohammad Kaif for inaccurate claims. (Photo by Francois Nel/Getty Images)

Big Change in India’s XI! No Jasprit Bumrah vs Oman?

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel. SUBSCRIBE NOW!

Jasprit Bumrah's tweet in response to Mohammad Kaif (Screengrab)

Poll Do you agree with Mohammad Kaif's assessment of Jasprit Bumrah's bowling strategy? Yes, he has a valid point No, Bumrah knows his best strategy

India pacer Jasprit Bumrah has publicly responded to former cricketer Mohammad Kaif ’s remarks on his workload management, dismissing his claims as inaccurate.On Thursday evening, Kaif raised concerns about how Bumrah was being used in white-ball cricket. Referring to the Asia Cup, he pointed out that under Suryakumar Yadav’s captaincy, Bumrah bowled three overs with the new ball rather than saving himself for the death overs.“Bumrah under Rohit would generally bowl overs 1, 13, 17, 19. Under Surya, in Asia Cup, he bowled a three-overs spell at the start. To avoid injury, Bumrah these days, prefers to bowl while his body is warmed up. 1 over of Bumrah in the remaining 14 overs is a huge relief for batters, against stronger teams at World Cup, this could hurt India,” Kaif wrote on X.Bumrah has now responded to the former India batter’s post, quoting it with a sharp dismissal. “Inaccurate before inaccurate again,” he wrote.The pacer’s reply suggests he felt Kaif’s assessment of his bowling strategy was not only incorrect this time but had been off the mark on previous occasions as well.Despite Kaif’s concerns, selectors have shown full confidence in Bumrah. He was recently included in India’s squad for the two-Test home series against West Indies, beginning October 2 in Ahmedabad.Chairman of selectors Ajit Agarkar confirmed that Bumrah is fit and ready after a break following the England tour.Bumrah’s response comes at a crucial time, with India preparing for the Asia Cup final against either Pakistan or Bangladesh on Sunday. His role with the ball will again be crucial to India’s chances, whether at the start of the innings or in the death overs.
Article Summary: Jasprit Bumrah has responded to Mohammad Kaif's comments on his workload management. Kaif had said that under Suryakumar Yadav’s captaincy, Bumra bowled three overs with the new ball rather than saving himself for the death overs. The former India batter added that this could hurt India against stronger teams at the World Cup. India face either Pakistan or Bangladesh in the Asia Cup final.

Article Title: 'We are immune to the crowd': Smriti Mandhana's bold claim as women's ODI World Cup nears
Article Text:
Smriti Mandhana celebrates after scoring a hundred during game three of the ODI series vs Australia at Arun Jaitley Stadium (Photo by Pankaj Nangia/Getty Images)

India Women’s ODI World Cup 2025 Squad | Shafali Verma misses out | Full Press-conference

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel. SUBSCRIBE NOW!

Poll Do you believe that the Indian women's cricket team has a stronger chance of winning the ODI World Cup this year compared to previous tournaments? Yes, absolutely! No, I don't think so.

India vice-captain Smriti Mandhana believes the women’s team carries a stronger sense of belief heading into the ODI World Cup, with every player confident of being a match-winner. India will begin their campaign against Sri Lanka in Guwahati on September 30.Mandhana underlined how preparation has changed the mindset within the group. “I think our belief has changed a lot and it only changes with what work you put behind it. When the effort is there, the fight will always be there. That’s one thing that has changed with this team — everyone believes they are match-winners,” she told JioStar.The left-handed opener also admitted that the last edition of the tournament was difficult to take as an athlete. “The last T20 World Cup was something which hit me quite a lot. I thought to myself, ‘I don’t want to feel like this as an athlete in my life’. Post that, a lot of fitness and nutritional changes have come into place,” she added.Mandhana said the squad is eager to experience the support of home fans. “We all have been waiting for this World Cup. A lot of things have changed for women’s cricket in India since 2013 when I was a kid.I am really excited to see how the stadiums turn out and the way they will support. The Women’s Premier League (WPL) has made us immune to the loud crowd as well. Nothing can beat people cheering India at the stadiums,” she said.Looking back on her debut, Mandhana recalled the emotions of receiving her first India jersey. “I remember I was 17 when I got the India jersey in my room. I don’t think I can forget it. I wore it and sent the photos to my parents and my brother. They were very emotional,” she said.Captain Harmanpreet Kaur reflected on her own journey. “As a girl, it was very hard for me to dream about playing for the country. I always wanted to open with Virender Sehwag, not knowing that you can’t play in a men’s team,” she said.All-rounder Deepti Sharma credited head coach Amol Muzumdar for encouraging the team to push beyond comfort zones. “Our mindset has changed now a bit, regardless of the team we are facing and the format. We focus on what we can pull off and always talk about positive things and apply the same on the ground. We talk to Amol sir in our practice sessions and the main thing is to try and come out of our comfort zone to plan for different situations,” she said.
Article Summary: India will begin their campaign against Sri Lanka in Guwahati on September 30. Vice-captain Smriti Mandhana believes the women’s team carries a stronger sense of belief heading into the ODI World Cup. Captain Harmanpreet Kaur reflected on her own journey.
